importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The study began in 2018 and continued into 2025, showing a longitudinal research effort on ant behavior and disease response.

keyTakeAways: Ants, specifically black garden ants (Lasius niger), modify their nest architecture in response to a lethal fungal pathogen, Metarhizium brunneum.
Infected ants self-isolate, and healthy ants—especially nurses—distance themselves from foragers, demonstrating proactive social distancing.
Nest structures become more compartmentalized, less interconnected, with wider entrances and longer travel routes, reducing disease transmission.
These structural and behavioral changes work together to provide effective protection against epidemics, representing a form of 'architectural immunity'.
The study, published in Science, shows the first documented case of a non-human social species altering its physical environment in response to a disease threat.
The findings suggest that principles from ant colony behavior could inspire human-designed public spaces to reduce disease spread.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Black garden ants (Lasius niger) modify both their social behavior and nest architecture in response to a lethal fungal pathogen, Metarhizium brunneum. Infected ants self-isolate, and healthy ants—especially nurses—increase their distance from foragers, showing proactive social distancing. The ants also build more compartmentalized, less interconnected nests with wider entrances and longer travel routes, which reduces disease transmission. This combination of behavioral and structural changes represents a form of 'architectural immunity' and marks the first known case of a non-human social species actively modifying its physical environment in response to disease. The research, published in the journal Science, suggests that principles observed in ant colonies could inspire new human-designed public spaces and urban planning strategies to reduce disease spread.
title: Ants Design Colonies to Reduce Disease Spread — A Model for Human Architecture
